intro: Gynocardia antisyphilitica, commonly known as the syphilis plant, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its umbellate inflorescence. The plant has slender, branched stems and small, greenish-white flowers that bloom in summer. Its leaves are pinnately divided, contributing to its ornamental value in gardens. Despite its historical association with syphilis, it is not toxic and has been used in traditional medicine for various purposes.
